verses.text: Then Moses answered, 'But look, they will not believe me or listen to my voice, for they will say, ‘The LORD did not appear to you.’'
verses.comment: Moses expresses hesitation, foreseeing the Israelites’ doubt. This highlights the human tendency to question divine revelation until it is confirmed by signs.

verses.text: The LORD said to him, 'What is that in your hand?' He said, 'A staff.'
verses.comment: God often uses ordinary things for extraordinary purposes. The staff, a simple shepherd's tool, becomes a symbol of divine authority.

verses.text: 'Throw it on the ground,' He said. So he threw it on the ground, and it became a serpent, and Moses ran from it.
verses.comment: The transformation of the staff into a serpent evokes both awe and fear, echoing the sign's supernatural origin.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, 'Reach out your hand and seize it by the tail.' So he reached out his hand and caught it, and it became a staff in his hand.
verses.comment: Moses' obedience in grasping the serpent demonstrates faith over fear. The restoration to a staff signals God's power to restore and protect.

verses.text: 'That they may believe that the LORD, the God of their fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has appeared to you.'
verses.comment: This sign is meant to confirm Moses' divine mission. Citing the patriarchs roots Moses' mission in continuity with God’s covenants.

verses.text: Again the LORD said to him, 'Put your hand inside your cloak.' So he put his hand inside his cloak. When he took it out, his hand was leprous, white as snow.
verses.comment: Leprosy symbolizes impurity and sin. The sign’s reversal prefigures later miracles of healing, such as those of Christ.

verses.text: Then He said, 'Put your hand back inside your cloak.' So he put his hand back inside, and when he took it out, it was restored like the rest of his flesh.
verses.comment: The restoration reinforces God’s authority to heal. These signs often anticipate the sacraments, where outward signs convey inward grace.

verses.text: 'If they do not believe you or pay attention to the first sign, they may believe the latter sign.'
verses.comment: God provides multiple signs to confirm His message, showing patience and accommodation to human weakness.

verses.text: 'But if they will not believe even these two signs or listen to your voice, then you shall take some water from the Nile and pour it on the dry ground. The water you take from the Nile will become blood on the dry ground.'
verses.comment: Turning water to blood foreshadows the plagues and points ahead to miracles where ordinary elements become signs of judgment or grace.

verses.text: But Moses said to the LORD, 'Please, my Lord, I am not eloquent—not in the past, nor since you have spoken to your servant; for I am slow of speech and tongue.'
verses.comment: Moses’ humility reveals his reliance on God’s power, not his own ability. God frequently chooses the humble for significant roles.

verses.text: The LORD said to him, 'Who made man's mouth? Who makes him mute or deaf, seeing or blind? Is it not I, the LORD?'
verses.comment: God affirms His sovereignty over human abilities and limitations. This verse also raises profound mysteries about divine providence.

verses.text: 'Now go, and I will be with your mouth and teach you what you shall speak.'
verses.comment: God promises to guide the messenger’s words. This is a precursor to the sending of the Spirit, who guides leaders and prophets in truth.

verses.text: But he said, 'Please, my Lord, send someone else.'
verses.comment: Despite reassurance, Moses’ reluctance continues. This theme of unwilling prophets echoes throughout Scripture, underscoring God’s patient calling.

verses.text: Then the anger of the LORD was kindled against Moses, and He said, 'Is there not Aaron, your brother, the Levite? I know that he can speak well. And behold, he is coming out to meet you, and when he sees you he will rejoice in his heart.'
verses.comment: Aaron’s role begins here as Moses’ spokesman. This sets a pattern of delegated spiritual authority and mediation, which echoes forward into later leadership models.

verses.text: You shall speak to him and put the words in his mouth, and I will be with your mouth and with his mouth, and will teach you both what to do.
verses.comment: God’s grace covers human weakness by enabling collaboration. The pattern of God mediating His word through chosen leaders continues into the New Covenant.

verses.text: He shall speak for you to the people, and he shall be your mouth, and you shall be as God to him.
verses.comment: This establishes a mediator role, anticipating the ultimate Mediator, Christ, but also a continuing understanding of spiritual authority delegated to others.

verses.text: And take in your hand this staff, with which you shall do the signs.
verses.comment: The staff that becomes the instrument of God’s wonders symbolizes God's active presence through material means.

verses.text: Then Moses went back to Jethro his father-in-law and said to him, 'Please let me go back to my brothers in Egypt to see whether they are still alive.' And Jethro said to Moses, 'Go in peace.'
verses.comment: Moses shows respect for family authority. The peaceful blessing foreshadows the harmony between personal calling and spiritual office.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Moses in Midian, 'Go back to Egypt, for all the men who sought your life are dead.'
verses.comment: God’s providence removes obstacles to Moses’ mission, similar to the safeguarding of the infant Jesus (Matt. 2:19-20).

verses.text: So Moses took his wife and his sons, set them on a donkey, and returned to the land of Egypt. And Moses took the staff of God in his hand.
verses.comment: Moses’ journey with family prefigures other holy families sent on divine missions. The phrase 'staff of God' signals God’s own power at work through chosen instruments.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, 'When you go back to Egypt, see that you do all the wonders before Pharaoh which I have put in your hand. But I will harden his heart, so that he will not let the people go.'
verses.comment: The hardening of Pharaoh’s heart introduces the interplay between divine sovereignty and human response, a theme discussed throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Then you shall say to Pharaoh, 'Thus says the LORD: Israel is my son, my firstborn.'
verses.comment: Calling Israel 'firstborn' prefigures the unique Sonship of Christ (cf. Matt. 2:15). God’s familial relationship with His people is foundational to understanding salvation history.

verses.text: 'And I say to you, “Let my son go, that he may serve me.” But if you refuse to let him go, behold, I will kill your son, your firstborn.'
verses.comment: This foreshadows the Passover, where deliverance comes through a firstborn’s death. The firstborn concept will be fulfilled in Christ’s redemptive sacrifice.

verses.text: At a lodging place on the way, the LORD met him and sought to put him to death.
verses.comment: This mysterious incident underscores the seriousness of covenant obligations. Obedience, even for chosen leaders, is necessary for God’s favor.

verses.text: Then Zipporah took a flint and cut off her son's foreskin and touched Moses' feet with it, and said, 'Surely, you are a bridegroom of blood to me!'
verses.comment: Zipporah’s action fulfills the covenant of circumcision (Gen. 17:14). The 'bridegroom of blood' phrase reflects the cost and necessity of covenant participation.

verses.text: So He let him alone. It was then that she said, 'Bridegroom of blood,' because of the circumcision.
verses.comment: Once the covenant is observed, God relents. This passage emphasizes sacramental signs as necessary for entering the community of faith.

verses.text: The LORD said to Aaron, 'Go into the wilderness to meet Moses.' So he went and met him at the mountain of God and kissed him.
verses.comment: The meeting of Moses and Aaron on the holy mountain signifies unity in God’s mission, anticipating apostolic collegiality.

verses.text: And Moses told Aaron all the words of the LORD with which He had sent him, and all the signs that He had commanded him to do.
verses.comment: The faithful transmission of God’s message and signs establishes the principle of apostolic tradition, preserving true teaching.

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron went and gathered together all the elders of the people of Israel.
verses.comment: This official assembly of elders foreshadows the leadership structure among God’s people, ensuring teaching and order.

verses.text: Aaron spoke all the words that the LORD had spoken to Moses and did the signs in the sight of the people.
verses.comment: The public display of signs authenticates the message. Teaching is accompanied by living witness and visible signs.

verses.text: And the people believed. And when they heard that the LORD had visited the people of Israel and that He had seen their affliction, they bowed their heads and worshiped.
verses.comment: Faith is awakened through the combination of word and sign. God’s saving visitation to His people anticipates later acts of redemption and the response of faith and worship.
